note.p: Career: Entered the Navy (1787); studied astronomy and meteorology for five months under Rev Henry Ussher, first Andrews Professor of Astronomy, University of Dublin and first Director of Dunsink Observatory (1788); saw much active service; Commander (1800); worked on establishing a semaphore system capable of transmitting messages from Dublin to Galway in eight minutes with his future father-in-law Richard Lovell Edgeworth (1803);surveyed the entrance of the Rio de la Plata (1807); surveyed the coast of Karamania; Hydrographer to the Admiralty (1829-1855); awarded DCL Oxford (1839); Rear Admiral (1846); retired (1855); devised the Beaufort scale of wind strength and an alphabetical categorization of the weather's various states; Beaufort Sea, near the current Alaskan oil fields is named after him; Beaufort prize is awarded annually to the best student of navigation at the Royal Naval College, Dartmouth
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; Irish Innovators
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc 1857-1859 vol 9 pp 524-527
References: R W Home, 'The Royal Society and the Empire: the colonial and Commonwealth Fellowship. Part 1. 1731-1847' in NR 2002 vol 56 pp 307-332
D Carr Agnew, 'Robert Fitzroy and the myth of 'Marsden Square': Transatlantic rivalries in early marine meteorology' in NR 2004 vol 58 pp 21-46
